subject: Design
title: The Streamline Era: When Everything Got Aerodynamic
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Streamline Era: When Everything Got Aerodynamic usable.

hook.text: In the 1930s, designers made toasters, radios, and pencil sharpeners look like they could fly. None of them needed to.

buildup.text: Streamlining removed sharp edges and added teardrop shapes to everything during the Great Depression.

discovery.text: The style signaled progress and optimism. In hard times, a futuristic toaster promised a better tomorrow.

twist.text: Aerodynamics are useless on a stationary toaster. Streamlining was pure psychology, not engineering.

climax.text: Streamlining proved that industrial design sells emotion â€” hope, speed, modernity â€” not just function.

punchline.text: Streamlining a toaster is pointless. But it sold millions.

quiz.question: Why were stationary objects streamlined in the 1930s?
options: To signal progress and sell optimism during the Depression
